column5: Same lol. Alcohol for worse!
Of course. Go find a therapist!

Me too! Going on about 9 years since my first panic attack. Trust me it will go away. This too shall pass is what I always tell myself. If you keep doing the right things you will wake up one day soon and realize that you aren‚Äôt anxious. Make sure you write down how you feel in the morning, keep a journal. This allows you to track your progress in recovery. I guarantee one day you‚Äôll wake up and not want to write anything down, BECAUSE YOU FEEL SO MUCH BETTER!!! Always here to talk if you want to message

I‚Äôm the same exact way. Usually it passes for me over time. I think things that help is meditation when those feelings come on and not dwelling on the feelings in your bed. If you feel uncomfortable in bed, get up and take a walk or start your day earlier, eventually every morning will become easier as a result. Also please go see a therapist. Verbalizing your concerns out loud is very helpful for me!

Interesting. However, if it‚Äôs your dream, how could I feel the same exact way as you? How do I know that your not just a figment in my dream? Sorry not meaning to be scary lol. Another note is that try and take notice when you find yourself stressing over little things during the day. You should feel that when u stress about real life, the dream starts to fade. Like I‚Äôll go a couple hours without noticing it and remind myself to feel like shit again haha

I have a very similar situation. What you‚Äôre describing is called derealization/depersonalization. I have suffered from it for 10 years. It‚Äôs a symptom of anxiety. The weird thing is the derealization has really shaped the person I am today. After a while of suffering, I realized that if I was in a dream, I wasn‚Äôt going to ever wake up, so I might as well deal with it. As soon as I realized that, the feeling started to diminish. Obviously therapy and meds do help. Talking to someone helps a lot. It feels uncomfortable at first because everything seems so distorted, but the more you distract yourself from the feeling, the easier it gets. It also helps to engage in activities that are thrilling. I really like doing stand up comedy. It‚Äôs hard to feel the derealization while you‚Äôre standing in front of people trying to make them laugh. Kinda reminds you that you‚Äôre human. Working out has really helped me too. I know how uncomfortable this feeling is! I hope this helps a little
Setraline 50mg for me for 5 years! Works pretty well with a few hiccups here and there

I‚Äôve worked in a restaurant for a few years! First off, everyone drops stuff! It just happens unfortunately. I once dropped 25 champagne glasses from my shoulder in front of a full restaurant! Another time I spilled champagne on an old lady‚Äôs head! It happens. As far as the customers, whenever I feel nervous or anxious, I just try to think of when I eat at restaurants. I start to realize that I never really pay attention to the server or care if they make little mistakes. Once you realize that the people just want to eat, it becomes a lot easier! I used to have to write everything down because I was so scared that I would forget and now I can take orders just by memory! It just takes time and practice, mistakes will happen just know that no one really cares as much as we think they do

I‚Äôm currently going through this same thing. It‚Äôs weird, the last spell I had lasted until I blew out my knee playing basketball. It was almost like the instant I felt my acl snap, the derealization went away. I guess just distracting myself with something else helped
I think it is helping in the long run. The dp/dr is honestly probably a result of getting sober. I too suffer from dp/dr and the only times I get it now is when I try to quit nicotine
Don‚Äôt give up! We care
I‚Äôm actually color blind and depressed haha
Meditation! Try insight timer app
Go to the ‚Äúcoping with anxiety‚Äù section and try one!
Meditation! Insight timer app. It helps and it‚Äôs free!
I‚Äôm on like day 9 :/ getting better each day though. It will get better. I realized one day you just wake up and don‚Äôt even realize you‚Äôre not anxious anymore. It‚Äôs weird

Yes! If I‚Äôm not in a bout of anxiety I sleep and function like a normal human being (for the most part). If I feel normal I still have the anxiety but it doesn‚Äôt really bother me as much as the dark times. Doesn‚Äôt bother me at all really. I‚Äôve noticed throughout the years that if you just get up and do the things that your mind tells you not to do, you will slowly start to get back to yourself. You and I have to proactive instead of reactive. I‚Äôve waited for it to get better by doing nothing and it takes MUCH longer than if I just struggle through my normal routine
Literally all the things you mentioned help. Plus if you‚Äôre into exercise it def helps. Once you get these things going in your life, it‚Äôs about staying the course and living one day at a time!
Me too! Love this

I literally could‚Äôve written this myself. We have the exact same experience. I used to go through it every couple months like you but it got fewer and farther between these past couple years. I‚Äôm in it right now and it just absolutely sucks. Feels like all the progress I made was for nothing. I FEEL YOU. Here if you wanna chat
I think you have all the answers you are looking for, it just doesn‚Äôt all seem to make sense right now. Talk to your dad and sister I‚Äôm sure they know exactly what you‚Äôre going through!

I just want to say that I have an extremely similar story to yours. When I was 15 I was sitting at my desk on the phone and I had the exact same thing. The way you question how a panic could happen just sitting at your desk has a simple answer. Anxiety does not discriminate! Time, place, person. It was very confusing for me the first time as well. I will tell you that it is highly unlikely that there is anything physically wrong with you. You are going through a very stressful period in your life. You may not realize it but the stressors of college can creep up on you all at once. Do any of your parents have a history of anxiety? My mom has it very similar to me. I take Zoloft 50mg and I have for several years. It doesn‚Äôt cure the anxiety, that‚Äôs up to you. However, it makes the panic attacks few and far between and the daily anxiety much more manageable. I can‚Äôt remember what your last question was hahah I‚Äôll comment under this. Oh ya similar symptoms. In my experience, the symptoms you described are indicative of a panic attack. Certain medications don‚Äôt work for everyone and it‚Äôs really about trial and error. Don‚Äôt get discouraged about going back to college. The rhythm and routine that you are used to will help you feel better. Try talking to a therapist about what‚Äôs going on, that really helped for me. Hope this helps
If she‚Äôs a true friend, she will understand! If anything it will probably make you two closer. It will also feel like a big weight off of your shoulders

Change is hard. I have the same issue. I‚Äôve noticed that sticking to the script and doing your normal routine will help normalize the things and you will start to feel more comfortable. If you like the job, stick to it! You got this

I‚Äôm currently going through what I call a ‚Äúspell‚Äù of anxiety. However, I can‚Äôt confidently say that I went almost a year without any significant or overwhelming anxiety. This is coming from someone who has been dealing with it for 9 years. Each year getting better than the last. When I fall into these spells, I tend to forget how good I felt before. You just have to remind yourself that your brain is a very powerful thing. Just because it tells you that you probably will feel bad forever, just know it CERTAINLY isn‚Äôt true. Trust me:)
Please don‚Äôt give up. I promise it does get better
Look up derealization/depersonalization
Trust me! It gets easier!

Hey man idk if you take medication already but that might be something to check out. Also verbalizing your thoughts really helps with a therapist or a close friend/family member. Not just texting but actually speaking your feelings seems to help me a lot. I‚Äôve gone through the exact same thing you‚Äôre talking about as far as feeling like a completely different person. Exercise, meditation, really help. I‚Äôve noticed that when I‚Äôm having a panic attack just taking deep breathes usually gets my heart rate down. As a more broad plan of action, just continuing to do the normal daily things that you usually do when you‚Äôre not anxious, will get you feeling better almost immediately. Don‚Äôt let the anxiety consume you. If someone invites you out, but you‚Äôd rather stay home because you‚Äôre anxious, go anyways. Go on that date. Do all the things you normally do (healthy things obviously) and you should start to feel a lot better

Ya I see what you‚Äôre saying. When the anxiety is making it hard to focus at work, the medication should make it easier by suppressing the racing thoughts and worry from anxiety. If anything it should be easier to work! I haven‚Äôt noticed any substantial brain fog from setraline, if anything that is one of my anxiety symptoms before setraline!

It‚Äôs a toss up. On one hand I don‚Äôt want to be dependent on a drug to make me feel good, on the other hand this anxiety for me is biological to some degree. It runs in my family and I genuinely believe I have some chemical imbalance in my brain. Say you had diabetes for example. Would you just not taking the medication? I think society is growing a lot in terms of stigma and allowing people taking medications to feel okay about it. If I‚Äôm feeling good, then life is good :)

Hey man. I‚Äôve been on the same exact setraline 50mg for years now and I can confidently say that minus a total of maybe 3 months in the past 5 years, my anxiety and health anxiety have been under control and manageable. I wouldn‚Äôt say cured because obviously there‚Äôs flare ups and it doesn‚Äôt just magically go away with drugs. However, a combination of medication, therapy, and healthy living has allowed me to go close a year without having any abnormal and debilitating anxiety. Hope this helps. Give it a try!
Tell them. It will feel like a great weight has been lifted off your shoulders. If your son was struggling you would want to know right?
Seeing your normal doctor will be a good start and then they can refer you to a psychiatrist who prescribed the medication

Sounds like you have health anxiety my friend. I‚Äôm by no means a doctor but I have 9 years of anxiety experience. Anxiety can present a lot of physical symptoms. I‚Äôm the type of person that likes to google all my symptoms to find the problem. DO NOT DO THAT. It will only make it worse. The thing about these symptoms with anxiety is that it‚Äôs a downward spiral cycle. The numbness scares you and you being scared about it feeds the symptoms. Have you noticed that when your mind is busy on other things that the symptoms seem to go away or diminish? As someone with anxiety I experienced a lot of the same symptoms as you. For months I dealt with numbness in my legs, arms, face and hands. I felt like my balance was off as well as my vision. I was thoroughly convinced that I had a brain tumor or MS. Even though I knew that I had anxiety, I did not believe that it could just be my mind playing tricks on me. I have a similar story to you. College athlete, outgoing guy, love the spotlight. However, anxiety does not discriminate. For some anxiety manifests due to outside factors such as childhood trauma and other traumatic events. My life was really good on paper. It just hit me one day like a dump truck and that‚Äôs really scary. You seem to be relatively new to discovering and researching about anxiety. I implore you to ASK your doctor to be referred to a psychiatrist or psychotherapist to discuss what you‚Äôve told us. I truly think if you open up with those professionals, it will make you feel like things are starting to make sense. As far as the physical symptoms go, when you can distract your mind , they seem to start to go away. Unless there is an actual physical problem, which in this case there doesn‚Äôt seem to be any. Doctors are very good at their jobs. Hoped this helped sorry for rambling a bit.
Not sure about how your nutrition is, but a combination of a healthy diet and exercise works wonders for me! Easier said than done however. Especially during the holidays

Anxiety presents so many phsyical symptoms because of the chemicals released during the fight or flight response. Mine are similar. I start to feel like I‚Äôm in a dream or things are just off and wrong. I get naseous and weak and tingling sensations. I guess that might not help your symptoms go away, but I just want you to realise that it‚Äôs nothing more serious than anxiety. The mind is a very powerful thing
It does get better. I used to have it daily too. Medication and therapy helped a lot with exercise. You can do this

I‚Äôve noticed that even though it feels like you‚Äôre faking it, the best way to get through those things is to just embrace it. I was dreading the thought of coming home while anxious and after a few days of feeling bad for myself and pissing everyone else off, I decided to just try and act like I was having a good time. By the end of the trip home I felt better than before I came and actually enjoyed myself
Just happened to me that way as well. I was super dissapointed because I was doing well for almost a year:/
You matter to me
Stay busy. That‚Äôs my only advice. I think a lot about that stuff too and if I distract myself enough, those thoughts seem to go away
Message me!
The longer you keep distracting yourself over time. The less it will come back! I‚Äôm sure your brothers will say the same thing!

Sounds very familiar to me. Part of what makes the first panic attack so scary is that you don‚Äôt know what it is. What you‚Äôre currently experiencing is what I call ‚Äúhangxiety‚Äù like an anxiety hangover. Even though you aren‚Äôt still having an actual attack, your body is still on edge from the attack and you may feel little mini attacks come and go

I have a very similar story to you buddy. When I was 15 I got a bad cold and my mom gave me Sudafed. I had a horrible reaction to it which gave me my first panic attack. The main symptom after the panic attack was derealization. I thought I was going to be that way forever. I thought I would never get out of that mind state. I also thought I was going insane or schizophrenic, but that‚Äôs just the anxiety talking and you have to keep telling yourself that. I slowly worked to feel like myself again, it took a very long time, however everyone is different. Since then I have had a few panic attacks and some of them have been from weed. The best way for me to do defeat my derealization was to distract my mind in things that forced me to be present. Whether it was basketball, working out, video games, anything where I wasn‚Äôt stuck in my head. It may seem hard at first and like its not working, but I promise you it gets better. You won‚Äôt feel like this forever and you just have to take care of your body
Yes it‚Äôs so strange. I love my family but it feels like I just wanna be alone

Hey I really resonate with your story. It‚Äôs been about a year since I had a real panic attack but I‚Äôm going through a bunch now for certain reasons. Wondering if I could direct message you and catch your advice!
I‚Äôm up. I feel you. Let‚Äôs do this together and calm ourselves down

Do you have health insurance? 

Everything you listed is a ‚Äúwhat if‚Äù not a certainty. Therefore, it would only be logical to consider the other side of that ‚Äúwhat if‚Äù. What if everything goes great. What if you absolutely kill it in school and start an amazing career because of it. What if everything works out. I highly recommend finding a therapist and psychiatrist IF you have insurance. If not, you can still see these people to help you it will just be more expensive. You can do this! You‚Äôre ready and able to conquer your fears
Congrats! That‚Äôs a big step honestly. One small victory at a time. String a few more of those together and you will feel more comfortable each time. Keep workin!

I would really recommend trying a different medication if you haven‚Äôt already. Also trying to find a new therapist if you could. In my personal experience with anxiety it took me Atleast 2 years to feel okay with my anxiety. Most recently I‚Äôve gone 9 months without an anxiety/panic attack and it‚Äôs been so great. Had one a week ago and feel like I‚Äôm back where I started. I totally get you. I want to avoid everything I want to cry and sleep all day and throw up. Trust me I know exactly how you feel. I think honestly through all the medication and therapy, the only thing that truly got me through it was doing the things that I was afraid of. On Wednesday I was so fucking close to calling off work for a panic attack. I was literally trembling in my bathroom. Sometimes I lose this battle but this time I told myself YOU HAVE TO FUCKING GO. and I did. It was so shitty. I somehow finessed my way into leaving early but I did it. It was a small victory for me that day. Once you string those together, it becomes easier as time goes on. Don‚Äôt give up, I believe in you so much because I empathize

Trust me it does get better I promise you. I felt the exact same way that you did for over a year when I was 15. Crying everyday, waking up with the same dreadful feeling of anxiety, I know what it‚Äôs like. But I promise you it does get better. You have to give time it‚Äôs own time. You won‚Äôt feel this way forever. Try to take control of your life and be as  positive as possible. You will get out of it
Same.  It may suck the first couple times. But once you train your brain it gets easier
Thanks Kevin I‚Äôm on board with you. Let‚Äôs kick some ass in 2020
Mmmhmmm lets do it
Amazing! Keep it going

I‚Äôm in the same boat man. My best advice and I‚Äôm thankful I can be open with my family, is telling them what you‚Äôre going through. I hope your family is supportive of you and if they are I‚Äôm sure that they will understand. No one has to be happy during the holidays, it‚Äôs just days. I‚Äôm the same way though, I like the routine of normal life without huge events and what not. Please tell them you will feel so much better after and maybe they can help with professional help
You‚Äôre right. I just hate being in it while it‚Äôs happening
I‚Äôm in the same boat :/  incredibly anxious
Of course!

That‚Äôs good. Meds have really helped me. I‚Äôve also tried a bunch because not one medicine works for everyone. Don‚Äôt be discouraged if it doesn‚Äôt work for you the first time around. I guess my advice is keep living a healthy lifestyle while your body reacts to the medicine because that will give you the most accurate results of whether or not it‚Äôs working!

If the doctors cannot find anything, it is more than likely anxiety. Doctors extremely good at what they do and the reason you don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs anxiety is because you don‚Äôt want to believe it. I can‚Äôt tell you how many times I‚Äôve been to the doctors for issues I thought were life threatening that turned out to be anxiety. The reason I know that is because when the anxiety went away, so did the physical issues. Once you can get your mind off the fact that there‚Äôs nothing physically wrong with you, you‚Äôll be able to feel better. Trust me I‚Äôve been in your situation a thousand times. Oh and stop googling your symptoms! If google was always right there would be no doctors!
Breathe! I had a bad one this morning. Ground yourself.
I just got through anxiety hives. They show up on my collarbone and my back. It happens because your body is trying to sweat from the anxiety but also fighting against it so it creates the rash

I used to not drink because it made my anxiety worse. More recently I had been drinking to cope with the anxiety lol. Currently I‚Äôm anxious and don‚Äôt want to drink at all. I guess it just fluctuates depending on your mind state
Thank you you too!

I‚Äôm having a hard time. I get incredibly anxious around the holidays even though I‚Äôm seeing my friends and family it feels like I‚Äôm not able to enjoy because of this anxiety and that makes it even worse. I want to be able to have fun these times especially since I rarely see my friends and family but I can‚Äôt help feeling this way help
Keep chugging along! Change is difficult. Life will knock you down sometimes and thats okay!
Same. It‚Äôs killing me. Feels like 2017 all over again
I‚Äôm in the exact same boat my friend. Had a real bad panic attack about it on Wednesday and have been in constant anxiety ever since. Looking for some reassurance that everything will be okay!
You as well my friend. Feel free to message me

You have to prioritize your health before a job. I‚Äôm in the same boat right now and I just told my boss that I needed a break because of a personal health problem. He was apprehensive but there‚Äôs really nothing he can say. I‚Äôm taking the time right now to figure out my life and see my doctors and all that stuff. I implore you to do the same if you can. If you want to quit, just tell them it isn‚Äôt the right fit for you. Or that you got a different job. Your happiness is your number one priority. Don‚Äôt forget that

I feel you. I‚Äôm laying in bed right now struggling with the idea of drinking a sip of water. Anxiety destroys my stomach and my appetite. The main problem is that it‚Äôs a vicious cycle, the anxiety makes you sick, but the less you eat, the sicker you get. Try something like protein shakes to take in nutrients. When I can‚Äôt eat solid foods, the shakes always help. Healthy food is so important for your recovery. As for the mental aspect, it‚Äôs okay that you were drinking. That was the past, now is the present. You are already on your way by choosing not to drink alcohol. Those places in your house remind you of bad times but that‚Äôs not you anymore. Those memories don‚Äôt define you. Try and stay focused on the present, and making yourself a happier, healthier person for the future

I feel you man. I don‚Äôt know what I was thinking picking it back up. I guess I felt better again but I know that just means I have to keep doing healthy things. How do you find that natural energy without coffee

I also wanted to add that my anxiety is particularly not about little things. I work a stressful restaurant job and staying busy is helpful. Basically if I can see it, it doesn‚Äôt really bother me. I look a lot at the big picture
Talk to you soon

I know man. I‚Äôm in the same boat. I completely empathize with you. Before this week I was relatively anxiety and panic free for Atleast 5 or 6 months. You can do it man. You will feel like yourself soon. Keep pushing along
I gotta check when I get home! I‚Äôll be gone for the holidays but I‚Äôll get back to you
That‚Äôs solid dude! I only just got to diamond 1. We should play sometime.

Anxiety makes you feel like you‚Äôre going insane. I‚Äôm currently in the depths of it. I‚Äôve tried a bunch of medications and have been settled on Zoloft for about 5 years now. Besides a few hiccups, it‚Äôs been really good! The problem with these meds is it isn‚Äôt like painkillers or Advil where it kicks in the same day. Sometimes it takes weeks to feel the full effects. Just try to focus on staying positive and seeing the light at the end of the tunnel. I promise you won‚Äôt feel this way forever

I feel you I literally almost didn‚Äôt go to work just now but I‚Äôm doing it because I know it‚Äôs good for me to get my mind off it

I know so well. It feels like if you forgot something really important at home but you don‚Äôt have time to go back and get it. However, you‚Äôre literally just lying in bed hahah. I used to have it everyday for months in the early years. All I can say is that it DOES get better and easier, I promise you that
Of course. Let me know if you ever want to chat. Currently in bed doing exactly what I told you not to do soooo hahah

I‚Äôve been dealing with anxiety for 9 years. 24m. For me mornings are always hardest in the thick of it. The second that I open my eyes, I feel fine but as soon as I realize that I‚Äôm awake I start getting the symptoms you listed. Like you said, I also get better as the day goes on. I take Zoloft 50mg. I‚Äôve noticed that the best way to deal with it is to get up as soon as you feel it, and start your day. This may seem tough if you haven‚Äôt had enough sleep,  but it will allow your mind to move from the anxiety and panic quicker. Over time, it will become easier for you to wake up and in turn, able to fall back asleep in the morning
I‚Äôve literally been freaking out about this all week. I can‚Äôt handle it. I NEED WORLD PEACE PLEASE

I feel like that too right now. I‚Äôm out of school now but for some reason coming home for the holidays makes me so incredibly anxious. I feel like my few days off will be ruined by anxiety. I am just going to try and be as positive as possible. If you don‚Äôt like your school don‚Äôt be afraid to transfer! I did it 3 times and was very happy the third!
I have literally the same story as you
Hit me upp
Getting better each day. Had a horrible anxiety attack with what I call an ‚Äúanxiety hangover‚Äù for the past couple days. Nights are always better for me. Mornings are hard. Staying positive

Trust me I know EXACTLY how you feel. I spent months and months just suffering from horrible heath anxiety thinking that I had HIV from unprotected sex. All the worrying is pointless and the only real way to end the worry is to get tested for HIV. It‚Äôs terrifying in that moment but once you get the results back you will be happy again

I‚Äôm a comedian with anxiety. Great combination right? My greatest pleasures in life are being on the stage in front of everyone, but that comes at a price. I‚Äôve noticed the thing that has helped me most is to realize that YOU ARENT THAT IMPORTANT. I know this sounds harsh, but people really don‚Äôt care that much. Take for example a zit on your face. It may feel like when you show up to work everyone is staring at your zit, but they aren‚Äôt. People have their own issues and problems that IMMENSELY outweigh whatever it is that you‚Äôre doing. Do you spend all day thinking about other people‚Äôs zits? The best way to be a successful performer is to just be yourself. If they don‚Äôt like you for that then they can GTFO
Your life matters. We care about you
Always here to talk Elliot!

The mind is extremely powerful, more than we know. Just as an example, I have been smoking daily for close to a year now. Not as long as you and not as often during the day, but similar in some regard. A panic attack when I wasn‚Äôt high about a month ago completely turned me off from it. I have literally no desire to smoke when I feel this anxious. Im not saying that you should force yourself to have panic attacks but maybe some distraction or a healthier replacement for smoking will help ease the tension. Maybe trying cbd instead. Idk you probably think this is useless but just trying to give an outside perspective on your situation
